182 ON THE PHILLIPS CATALYST SITE WITH HIGH CATALYTIC ACTIVITY BERND REBENSTORF Research Group on Catalysis, Inorganic Chemistry 1, Chemical Center, University of Lund, Box 124, S-221 00 Lund (Sweden) Summary FT-IR spectroscopy has been employed to study two catalyst samples with 0.5% Cr and 0.074% Cr on silica gel in ethylene polymerization at room temperature and in the adsorption of CO. In one of the two series of experiments studied, samples were reacted with ethylene at 200 C prior to further reaction with ethylene at room temperature. It was observed that the previously reported broad band at 2750cm"1 arising from the hydrocarbon group connecting the living polymer to the chromium(II) site was split into two bands situated at 2768 and 2725 cm-1, respectively. These bands have been assigned to the asymmetric and symmet- ric stretching vibrations of the methylene group. Previous experiments had shown that CO adsorption onto the active chromium(II)-A polymerization site led to bands in the IR spectrum at 2176 and 2170cm-1 (the latter after 200 C/ethylene treatment) and which exhib- ited a shift from 2179 cm" i for CO adsorbed on a chromium(II)-A surface species before reaction with ethylene. Similar shifts have now been observed with bands arising from CO adsorption on to chromium(II)-C surface species situated at 2187, 2181 and 2191 cm"1, respectively. A model for polymerization initiation and for the mechanism of the polymerization reaction is proposed, which involves dinuclear surface species and explains several results obtained with the (reduced) Phillips catalyst. Introduction The Phillips catalyst (Cr^) on silica gel) [1] has been shown to be a much more complicated system than anticipated hitherto by most scientists, who have tried to unravel its mysteries. To date, six different chromium surface species with oxidation numbers of two and three have been identified in the reduced Phillips catalyst, of which four have been shown to be catalytically active (Table 1). These reduced samples polymerized ethylene at room temperature with no induction time and at a low ethylene pressure, while the Phillips catalyst exhibits an induction time (ofca. 30 min) at 100 C and requires an ethylene pressure of 3 mPa [5]. Krauss and Stach therefore concluded that chromium(II) on silica gel is the active species in the Phillips catalyst [2 - 4]. It was shown later that this chromium(II) surface species may be present either in a highly coordinatively unsaturated state involving only two oxygen ions from the silica gel as ligands [chromium(II)- A] [6 - 9] or coordinated to an additional surface silanol group [chrom- ium(II)-B] [6, 7] or a surface siloxane group [chromium(II)-C] [8, 9]. It is also possible for surface species to exist with two silanol or siloxane ligands derived from the silica gel surface [10,11]. It should be noted that the chromium(II)-C species notation used by the author is different from that employed by other workers [11,12] who did not distinguish between the above two species (B, C) and used the terminology chromium(II)-B for both (see ref. 13). The picture became more complicated when it was demonstrated that even chromium(III) can form catalytically active surface sites on silica gel [14 - 21], and that mononuclear as well as dinuclear chromium(II) and chrom- ium(III) surface species may be formed [8, 9,13,16,18, 21 - 25]. Although im- pregnation studies with chromic acid and chromyi chloride did not provide evidence for the existence of dinuclear chromium(VI) surface species [26 - 29], data from low-temperature CO (FT)IR spectroscopic investigations clearly showed that CO can be adsorbed on to the chromium(II) species as a bridging ligand and must therefore be adsorbed on dinuclear chromium(II) surface species. The present state of affairs as seen by the author is listed in Table 1, where the main polymerization site of the Phillips catalyst is given as the dinuclear chromium(II)-A surface species. The hydrocarbon group connecting the living polymer to the active chromium(II) surface site has been identified in the IR spectrum as exhibiting a C H stretching vibration at 2750 cm"1 [31] which was assigned to a carbene group binding to the chromium. The present author later assigned this band to a methylene group which exhibited a deformation vibration at 1448 cm-1 [25]. However, virtually at the same time, other workers have assigned the latter band (but identified at 1450 cm"1) to a carbene group [12]. The chromium(III) surface site is also connected to a methylene group, but with a C H stretching vibration at 2685 cm-1 and a deformation vibra- tion at 1447 cm~1 [21]. A weak shoulder at 2650 cm"! was also noted in this case, but was not assigned. Adsorption of CO on the active chromium(II) site while the living polymer is still connected to the latter leads to a stretching vibration at 2170 or 2176 cm"1 depending on the polymerization temperature [12,13, 23, 25]. The author has shown previously [16] that on reaction of a chrom- ium(II)/silica gel catalyst with ethylene at temperatures above 140 C, the 173 polymerization species formed is more active than after reaction with ethylene at lower temperatures. These two chromium(II) polymerization species are investigated here in greater detail. Experimental The experimental conditions have been described previously [25]. In short, self-supporting discs from silica gel 60 (Merck 7733) containing 0.5% Cr or 0.074% Cr, respectively, were heated in an IR cell to 800 C, and then treated with oxygen which was evacuated several times. Following this procedure, the chromium(VI) was reduced with CO at 350 C. The remaining CO was evacuated at 300 C and the initial IR spectrum of the sample recorded at room temperature (see Table 2; Series A, spectrum 1). The cell was again filled with CO (lOkPa) and the second and third spectra were recorded at room temperature and at 145 C (100 Pa CO), respectively. The cell was again evacuated at 300 C and cooled to 200 C. Ethylene [pressure, 42 kPa (0.5% Cr) or 210 kPa (0.074% Cr)] was now reacted with the catalyst for 15 s and then removed by treatment in vacua for 5 min at 200 C, following which the fourth spectrum was recorded at room temperature (Table 2; Series A, spectrum 4). It should be noted that the Series B sample exhibits no spectrum 4; in this case the sample was only evacuated at 300 C. Both samples were then allowed to react with ethylene at room temperature in a similar manner as previously at 200 C, although in the case of the 0.074% Cr sample the polymerization time was 2 min. After further evacuation at 20 C, a fifth spectrum was recorded and thereafter the IR cell again filled with 10 kPa CO and a sixth and seventh spectrum recorded at room temperature and 145 C, respectively. All the IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet FT-IR spectrometer 20SXC with a resolution of 4cm~1 employing 4096-scan accumulation. A single spectrum required ca. 1 h to be fully recorded. Difference spectra were calculated by subtracting one spectrum from another. As the chromium concentration in the silica gel decreased, an increase in the percentage of active sites present relative to the total number of all chromium surface sites was observed, in agreement with previous observa- tions [16, 32], and was characterized by negative bands at 2120, 2100 and ca. 2035cm"1 in the spectra. In this respect it should be noted that although spectra 3 and 4 from the 0.074% Cr sample were multiplied by seven (the exact factor was 6.76), they are still approximately twice as strong as those from the 0.5% Cr sample (spectra 1 and 2, respectively). A similar trend was not observed with spectra arising from the poisoning of living polymerization sites with CO as depicted in Fig. 5. An explanation for this observation could be that because of the formation of large polymer molecules around each of the active sites present in the 0.074% Cr sample relative to the situation with the 0.5% Cr sample, a considerable number of the active sites in the 0.074% Cr sample may not be accessible to CO molecules. Discussion The splitting of the broad band at 2750 cm"1 in the IR spectrum arising from the hydrocarbon group binding the living polymer to the active chrom- ium(II) site into two bands at 2768 and 2725 cm~1 as noted above may be due to either a hydrocarbon group on the chromium(II)-A and chromium(II)-C surface sites or to the two bands of the methylene group of the living polymer. Because of the existence of a methylene deformation band at 1446 cm-1 and of two bands at 2685 and 2650cm"1 from methylene groups binding to chromium(III) sites, the latter possibility is favoured here. The splitting associated with the two methylene bands decreases from the normal value expected for methylene groups (2925-2853; 71cm"1) to a value of 43cm~1 when binding occurs with chromium(II) to a value of 35cm~1 for binding with chromium(III), while the arithmetic mean value for the two methylene bands also decreases from 2887.5 to 2746.5 to 2667.5 cm"!, respec- tively. There seems to be a connection between these two trends which can only be explained by assuming that they arise from a methylene group binding the polymer to the metal ion. The intensity ratio for the two methylene bands associated with linkage at chromium(II) and chromium(III) is higher than that for the methylene bands at 2925 and 2853 cm-1 depicted in Fig. 4. This suggests that the methylene group binding the living polymer to the chromium(II) and chrom- ium(III) sites is distorted from its normal tetrahedral configuration towards a square-planar arrangement. 180 The CO band at 2176 cm~1 has been assigned either to CO poisoning at the active chromium(II)-A polymerization site [13, 25] or to a mixed CO/ ethylene complex [12]. If both assignments are correct, this would mean that the electron densities of chromium(II) with one ethylene molecule or with one polymer chain attached are quite similar. This may be an important clue in unravelling the initiation mechanism. If the results reported above are taken together with those reported previously, it should be possible to explain them via a consistent model including several other features observed for the reduced Phillips catalyst: i. Polymerization initiation occurs solely through reaction of ethylene with active sites. ii. No other hydrocarbon groups besides methylene are formed in the initiation reaction. iii. Active chromium(II) and chromium(III) sites are paired (dinuclear). iv. Active chromium(II) sites rather than chromium(III) [16] form two different polymerization sites on reaction with ethylene at low and higher temperatures. v. The percentage of active polymerization sites relative to all chromium surface sites increases with decreasing chromium concentration (refs. 16 and 32, and results quoted above). c-/-'- T- -I'-- V ,0 ,/^/r ,C /Cr''H \^-c\^ - / ^-c^ \0 0 ^k s '"- ^ ^1\ D 0 ^/ \ ^c./ re i/ ^ ^&t'0 0 0 /k ^ ^ i ,Si\ /\\ Scheme 1. Such a model is depicted in Scheme 1 which is based on previous schemes advanced by the author. Hydrogen atoms attached to the hydrocar- bon group have been omitted to enhance the clarity of the scheme. Structure 181 A shows a model of the dinuclear chromium(II)-A surface species with two ethylene molecules, which are already orientated so as to allow the initiation reaction to proceed. Structure B illustrates a possible route whereby the initiation step may occur at low temperatures, in which two ethylene molecules form a hydrocarbon bridge between two chromium atoms. This model conforms with the conditions i, ii and iii listed above. Reaction with ethylene at higher temperatures would involve a different process requiring the possible involvement of structure C in Scheme 1. Here two hydrocarbon bridges are formed between the two chromium atoms, again conforming to the conditions i, ii and iii. Whereas a CO molecule can be adsorbed at the chromium atom in structure B opposite the carbon atom of one polymer chain, it must occupy a different position in structure C opposite two polymer chains. This explains the lower stretching vibration of CO adsorbed on the active chromium sites after reaction with ethylene at higher temperatures (2170 instead of 2176 cm"1). The existence of an additional ethylene molecule in structures D and E means that the latter will have to rotate through quite large and different angles in order to allow the formation of the transition complexes required by a cis-insertion mechanism for the polymerization reaction. Since the full angle of rotation for insertion by structure B is 180 while that for structure C is 135 , the latter should react more readily. This would explain why the polymerization species formed after reaction with ethylene at higher temperatures (structure C) exhibits a higher turnover number in the polymer- ization reaction [16]. The same argument may be applied to the dinuclear chromium(III) active site; in this case, it is not a second polymer chain which restricts the spatial arrangement of the ethylene molecule but the third oxygen ion. It has been observed that chromium(III) exhibits a similar high turnover number to that of chromium(II) after reaction with ethylene at high temperatures [16, 19]. The initiation reaction leading to structures B and C gives rise to chromium atoms with formal oxidation numbers of three (structure B) and four (structure C), respectively. If the same reactions occurred with chrom- ium(III), the formal oxidation numbers obtained would be four and five. The latter could be quite difficult to achieve and hence explain the observation listed under condition iv above. Condition v above may be explained in the following manner. To facilitate the initiation reactions, the active site needs sufficient space be- tween the two chromium atoms involved and this can be restricted by atoms from the silica gel support. This would explain why not all chromium(II)-A sites are polymerization-active. With a lower chromium concentration in the catalyst, chromium atoms might preferentially occupy those places on the silica gel surface that provide the most free space. This could explain why the percentage of active chromium sites increases with decreasing chromium concentration. The structures in the model presented above explain most of the experimental results obtained with the (reduced) Phillips catalyst and must 182 therefore have some bearing on the nature of the catalytic sites which exist therein.
